data.title: Deafening
data.text: We ordered house sausages.  They were served burnt.  Could not get a grasp of the taste with a charred casing.  Absolutely the noisiest restaurant we have ever visited.  Extremely painful experience.  Will not return.

data.title: Good food
data.text: We thought the food was very tasty and well presented. Good choice and the beet salad was particularly good. We opted for desserts which were really delicious. Our server was pleasant and helpful, she directed us to a nearby store which we needed to go to. The area we sat in was a little dark and the overall noise level is a little higher than we would have preferred.

data.title: Not Very Welcoming
data.text:
We've visited once for lunch in 2015 and twice this summer (2016). We were very excited to try out the rooftop patio this year. It is very nicely appointed, although you have to walk through a parking ramp to get to it. We were disappointed in the very limited food choices for lunch. Soup IS NOT served on the rooftop. If you want soup and salad for lunch, you must sit on the lower (street) level of the restaurant. The service wasn't all that great, either. Our waiter had an unwelcoming vibe. We're pretty low maintenance & usually good tippers (having been servers ourselves in previous lives).
The oxtail soup was very flavorful, maybe a tad salty. The salad and house dressing were good. The dressing was mildly Italian, with a smooth flavor (not the typical vinegar bite). 
We visited another day (after work) for Happy Hour, and were told there are no "Happy Hour" drink specials served on the rooftop. Well, la tee da!  We all love open air seating, especially on the rooftop, to enjoy Minnesota summers. 
I guess the owner believes they have a special enough space where their upscale guests don't mind limited food menus and have incomes to pay the higher prices for food and drink. 
My friends and I visit upscale places like Kincaids, Meritage, the St. Paul Hotel, W.A Frost, etc. They have specials that make their customers feel appreciated. We feel welcome there, as though they are happy we've made the effort to patronize their establishment. Not so, at Ox Cart.
We won't be returning.

data.title: beet salads for everyone
data.text: our group checks out beet salads all over town.  this one was good, not great.  there wasn't enough red beets in my opinion.  my cosmopolitan was delic!  We were put in the back room to help with the noise level.  it was still extremely noisy in that place...would have loved to have a door on that room!

data.title: Great Ale house with good food
data.text: Located next to the Saints Stadium in St. Paul, the Ox Cart is usually bustling with people, especially in the afternoon/early evening.  It is rather loud, so it is not a place to go if you want to talk.  The food is good...our service was average, the waitress seemed frazzled and not able to handle the tables she was assigned.  They have a roof-top that is ok.

data.title: Dinner before saints game
data.text:
Stopped here with a small group for dinner before the saints game on Saturday.
The good: the rooftop is very nice and the cheese curds were delicious
Th less good: the menu on the rooftop was pretty limited and service, though very friendly, was slow.

data.title: Great Choice Before the Game!
data.text: My husband and I went to the Oxcart before a Saints' game last week and enjoyed it very much.  It is a casual, but nice, place to get something to eat that is more than just bar food before a game at CHS Field.  We had a hot pastrami sandwich which was large enough to share.  That, and an appetizer, was more than enough.  We loved the warm wood that was everywhere inside, making it very cozy and friendly.

data.title: Rooftop fun
data.text: The rooftop is the place to be.  Get there early, as it does get crowded, but the atmosphere is wonderful.  Food selection on the roof is not as wide as in the main restaurant, but still a good variety.  Food was great as was the drink selection.

data.title: Very Nice, Must go to the Roof Top to experience it fully
data.text: ate here for an early dinner on a Saturday night, very good food. We had the lamb burger and bratwurst.  Very nicely done, nice to sit street side and people watch while enjoying a drink and a meal.  You MUST go to the roof top to experience it!  Excellent views allot of seating great atmosphere.

data.title: "Cheers" to the Roof Top
data.text: The Ox Cart opens a bar on the roof fairly recently....the view is amazing, the bartender was very attentive and I loved the cheese curds.  They were done with corn meal which was a little different and a lot good!  The dipping sauce was a spicy honey.  Definitely would come here again

data.title: Good Food, Indifferent Service
data.text: Our family (seven of us, ages 21-61) ate at the Ox Cart Ale House last night. We'd hoped for rooftop seating but it rained, so we sat downstairs inside. We are usually not a difficult group to please, and there were some things that were excellent----the quality of the food was top-notch. I had the best pastrami sandwich ever. Other offerings looked and tasted just as good. Now for the hard part: the interior space is so loud that we not only couldn't hear each other across the table, we couldn't even hear our server tell us the specials. When we mentioned the noise level, she said defensively, "well, sorry I didn't design the building". And it got less fun after that. Service was slow, and although the food was great, it took forever to get our bill (so we could leave and go somewhere less noisy to talk). When someone at her table asked for a pen to sign his Visa check, the server actually rolled her eyes (at another server nearby; we weren't supposed to see it, but we did). It was, to say the least, substandard service. Will we go back? Maybe, if we can sit on the roof, which allows breathtaking views of CHS Field and many other St Paul landmarks. It would be less noisy up there, and maybe the service would be better.

data.title: Drinks before the Saints game
data.text: This nice rooftop bar just blocks away from the field is a great place to go and have a drink before the game.  Trendy spot but the view is great, you have to love a roof top bar.

data.title: Nice view but $15 to park for an hour on a Sunday?
data.text: Stopped in for a beer to check the place out. Service was fine - not overly friendly but there weren't many tables so there was no wait. The view is nice - probably the best of the rooftops in St. Paul that I've been to. As we were leaving, we were discussing if we'd return & decided only if we were meeting others & it was a spot they selected but it wasn't a must-visit-again-spot for us - just not overly special in any way. We parked in their connected ramp. As we were going in, I was looking for posted prices but figured on a Sunday with no events in town, it couldn't be more than $7-$8 for an hour, especially considering the ramp is a dump and under construction. We were very wrong...parking was $15 for the hour. Not sure if that was a daily rate or what since we couldn't find the prices posted anywhere. That sealed the deal for us that we won't be returning. Yes, it was our fault for parking without knowing the prices but I trust business owners to be honest, up-front & to do the right thing....I know, my fault....

data.title: Outstanding food and service in dining room, strongly recommended
data.text:
On our way to a game at the St. Paul Saints stadium, we decided to have dinner here.  We stayed in the first floor dining room and then I went upstairs to check out the roof (more on that later).

We started out with the scallop appetizer - which I'd call one of the best tasting appetizers I've had anywhere in the US.  There were 3 substantial scallops, great cheese sauce, lots of mushrooms, really really good.  It's $18 - so not cheap but very, very good.

Our entrees were less expensive than the appetizer and also very good.  One of us had a grilled cheese sandwich and described this as excellent.  The other person had a grilled chicken sandwich was unusual and also excellent. Both came with a small salad.

The "bloody Mary" expert in the family had 2 of those which were very good.
Service was very pleasant, quick and responsive.

Then one of us went upstairs to check out the room.  From the dining room, you walk up a set of stairs, through the parking ramp to an elevator.

The view from the roof is dramatic.  I can't comment on the food or service.  But there are great views north toward the state capitol and east, toward the baseball field.

We really liked the food & service in the dining room and will return.

data.title: Rooftop happy hour
data.text: 4 of us spent a few hours on the rooftop this week. Amazing views of the city, if a little awkward to get to. Service was good, drinks were very good. Had the dry rub wings, which I highly recommend trying, and the cheese curds. Love the spiced honey dipping sauce. Will come back for dinner sometime. Nice place.

data.title: An Ale House Blues
data.text:
When you venture out to open a new restaurant, you definitely have to "keep your eyes on the road,
your hands upon the wheel", oh that's right, "your eyes on the road, your hands upon the wheel". Sure, there will be some growing pains, some bumps in the road, but your ultimate goal is to have a successful business and product to provide patrons. I'm not really sure what The Doors were singing about, but they might like our next stop and they may emphasize these lyrics to them as well. Because, there were a couple of bumps in the road, but thankfully, the food was exceptional!

The Ale House I'm talking about is the Ox Cart Ale House located near the all new CHS Field. A supreme location for any Saints game thanks to the addition of a rooftop patio with views of the stadium and the giant scoreboard. If it's a beautiful day, this is most definitely a place you want to be at, right? Well, unfortunately, this is where the bumps in the road have to be addressed.

My wife and I, along with our neighbors Dave and Jennifer, decided to keep the kids at home with sitters and go out on the town. Ox Cart Ale House was the pick for the evening and we were excited to check out the rooftop and enjoy the evening. But first, you have to try to get to the top! The elevator decided they didn't want to function properly, so it was 7 flights of stairs to the top, but the door was locked. Made a quick phone call and access granted. We found a table and this is where things went a little bumpy.

It appeared as though there was only about 3 or 4 servers for a completely packed and large rooftop patio as well as a full bar. It took quite a bit of time before we were addressed (which isn't a deal breaker and understandable when it is busy), but once our server came to take our drink order, she never placed it (I'll explain shortly). We also quickly ordered our meals for the evening as we checked our weather maps to see just how close the storms were - one rain drop, a dozen rain drops - I think it's time to head inside.

As we sat and contemplated our decision, our server continued to go take orders at other tables, eventually making her way to the kitchen. We ultimately decided to head downstairs and grab a table for a mad rush of everyone else deciding to do the same thing. I went to find our server and let her know to cancel or transfer our order while my party went downstairs to grab a table. Upon finding her (while running out some food to other guests), she informs me, "I never placed your order, so just head downstairs." Had we decided to stay on the rooftop, we would have never received our drinks and we would have been stuck in the rain before our food would have arrived.

Ok, some bumps in the road, whatever! It's the food we're after and it was outstanding! I briefly informed our new server of experience and I tried to keep her from feeling nervous. We placed our drinks order and they came quickly. Another quick bump in the road - the tap and menu selections differ between the main restaurant and the rooftop which was a little frustrating since there were beer selections we couldn't get. We then placed our food order and started our evening conversations (you had to be there!). Also, they have Red Stripe tall boys - TALL BOYS!! One of my faves...

Dave ordered the House Burger, His wife Jennifer ordered the Grilled Cheese, my wife ordered the Fried Chicken Sandwich and I went for the Lamb Burger. Time to let it roll, baby, roll!

My wife thought her Chicken Sandwich had some good flavor to it (it was the spice aioli), but didn't think she would really order it ever again. To be fair, when it comes to chicken, she tends to find it boring already, and likes it to be perfect (who can blame her?). I tried it and thought is was actually good, the aioli definitely helped and I would say give it a shot. Made with cornmeal batter, previously mentioned spicy aioli, dill pickles, lettuce and served on a milk bun.

Jennifer decided to add some bacon to her Grilled Cheese (smart decision - bacon makes everything awesome), made with caramelized onions, tomato, Emmentaler (a form of Swiss), mustard-dill sourdough.She had that thing gone pretty quickly! Her hubby tried it, liked it as well and while I didn't try it, I can't imagine it was terrible.

My Lamb Burger was an outstanding selection and one of my favorite, creative, non-traditional burgers I have had. I asked to have prepped to a medium and it's made with arugula, cucumber (which I removed), Aleppo pepper, Greek farmers cheese, mint and served on a milk bun. WOW! IF you like lamb, which I thoroughly do, you gotta try this one.

We saved the best for last! Dave's House Burger was the best meal of the night and will be included on my top 10 list - I'm A Meat Eater. Made with ground fresh daily and perfectly seasoned meat, caramelized onions, dill pickles, American cheese and served on a milk bun. Seriously, this was an awesome burger and I wanted seconds and even asked Dave if he wanted to trade. It was gone quickly!

We finished with some dessert adult beverages, watched a little domestic across the street, praised our server after speaking to the G.M. Dan and just enjoyed the rest of the evening. We may have gotten a little moist from the rain, made a poor decision to stop at a weird place called the Bedlam, but we had an awesome night making memories together! There was no Doors music heard during the evening, but there was some really bad elevator music at Bedlam!

Check this place out, but just keep an open mind if you venture to the rooftop!

data.title: Rooftop Hunger
data.text: Very disappointed with the barely there food choices.  This place makes it on beer and views, but done expect to be fed well. Even their signature sausage was dismal at best. Won't be recommending or returning.

data.title: The rooftop bar is, hands down, the best!
data.text: For our anniversary we stopped by for a drink on the rooftop.  I had the Standard and it was delicious!  The service was great, everyone was very friendly, and if you don't want to look at CHS field, you have the option of sitting on very comfortable patio furniture and quaint tables.  The flower pots are gorgeous!

data.title: New roof top bar - first visit
data.text:
The rooftop setup is great and the view is a big bonus.  

The menu is very limited.  Happy hour specials are not available on the rooftop.

We ordered the cheese curds which were undercooked  (not even melted inside).  We sent them back.  Second batch were better but still undercooked.  One person in our party had the chicken sausage and loved it.  Another Tried the lamburgers and really liked them. The beer was good.  However, cocktails were off and inconsistent.  Returned the Margarita.  One monitor had no mint in it....so go for beer or wine.  Server was fair...not very friendly.  When someone asked which Bourbon they  has she said "I don't know".... go for the beer and the view.  You'll be happy.  Avoid mixed drinks and cheese curds...

data.title: Just OK Summer Spot
data.text: I ate at Ox Cart over 4th of July weekend. The restaurant at street level is spacious and airy with large windows that open fully, so you will kind of feel like you are dining outside if you can't get seated on the rooftop. You have to walk through a parking lot then take an elevator (or several flights of stairs) to get to the rooftop patio. I was with friends who had viewed the menu online prior to meeting up, and were very disappointed to find that the rooftop has a modified, smaller menu. This should be noted on the website. I enjoyed my food, but my cocktail (selected because the waitress was raving about it) was so weak it couldn't have possibly had any liquor, so I felt pretty ripped off. Service was incredibly slow. The rooftop has a lot of seating, and living in the Midwest, it's nice to dine outside in these few precious warm months. You can probably find someplace better to do so.
